DataElement.preferredName: Fluorodeoxyglucose Positron Emission Tomography Injection Begin Time
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the time of day at which administration of an injection of a radioactive form of glucose started during diagnostic imaging with positron emission tomography.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to use of a syringe and needle to push a radioactive form of glucose into the body for the purpose of enhancing diagnostic imaging with positron emission tomography.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The radioactive form of glucose used in positron emission tomography (PET), a diagnostic imaging procedure.:A noninvasive imaging method that provides information about cellular activity (metabolic information).  It is used along with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) which provides information about the shape and size of the tumor (spatial information).

Concepts.definition: A positron-emitting radiopharmaceutical containing radioactive 2-deoxy-2-[18F] fluoro-D-glucose. With similar cell uptake as glucose (high in tumor cells), fludeoxyglucose F 18 is not dephosphorylated and further metabolized. (NCI04)

A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

Property.preferredDefinition: Use of a syringe and needle to push fluids or drugs into the body; often called a "shot."

Concepts.definition: Use of a syringe and needle to push fluids or drugs into the body; often called a "shot."

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the time at which an evaluation or assessment procedure is started.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Have a beginning, in a temporal, spatial, or evaluative sense.:the continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.

Concepts.definition: Have a beginning, in a temporal, spatial, or evaluative sense; the point in space or time where something begins.
The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.
